feed.title: Data Is Plural
feed.subtitle: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.01.31 edition
entry.content:
Groundwater levels, military surplus, study abroad, dot-gov metadata, and Taylorâ€™s colors.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Alexandra F has mapped and charted the locations and characteristics of â€œbog bodies,â€ using data from Roy van Beek et al. (featured in DIP 2023.02.15) and Overture Maps (featured in DIP 2023.08.09). Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.

Â 

Groundwater levels. To assess global trends in groundwater levels, Scott Jasechko et al. have analyzed data from ~170,000 monitoring wells in 40+ countries. The researchersâ€™ public datasets include annual groundwater levels â€œin all cases for which we have received permission from a database manager to post data,â€ amounting to more than 4 million measurements (59% of the total). The published records also include the boundaries of 1,600+ aquifer systems, â€œmanually delineated [â€¦] using maps and descriptions from 1,236 local and regional studies.â€ The studyâ€™s supplementary documentation describes each data source and method of access. Read more: Coverage in the New York Times, with detailed maps of Iran and Spain, and in Wired. [h/t Patrick Tanguay]

Â 

Military surplus. Through its Excess Defense Articles program, the US military offers free and reduced-price equipment to foreign governments. The Department of Defense publishes a spreadsheet of the programâ€™s authorizations and transfers, last updated in midâ€“2020 and going back to 2010. Each of the 4,100+ entries lists the foreign country, item description, transfer status, status date, whether it was a sale or grant, quantities (requested, allocated, accepted, rejected, delivered), â€œcurrentâ€ value, and acquisition value. Items range in size and significance, from vinyl tape (55 rolls authorized for transfer to Iraq in 2016) to Abrams tanks (including 178 provided to Morocco in 2018). [h/t David Vine]

Â 

Study abroad. Open Doors, an Institute of International Education initiative funded by the State Department, â€œis the only long-standing, comprehensive information resource on international students and scholars in the United States and on U.S. students studying abroad for academic credit.â€ Its annual reports provide aggregate statistics by country, field of study, and/or institution. For example: NYU hosted more international students (~25,000) than any other US university in the 2022â€“23 school year, followed by Northeastern (~21,000) and Columbia (~19,000); Italy, the UK, and Spain were the most popular destinations for US students in 2021â€“22. Related: The State Departmentâ€™s statistics on non-immigrant visas, including student visas. Previously: Data on Europeâ€™s Erasmus exchanges (DIP 2022.02.09). [h/t Kate Miller]

Â 

Dot-gov metadata. Father-son duo Luke and Elias Fretwell are grading government websitesâ€™ metadata. Starting with a dataset of 1,300+ federal domains maintained by the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, the Fretwells have tested whether each homepageâ€™s source code includes a <title> tag, certain Open Graph markers, and other key HTML metadata, which â€œcan have a significant impact on how citizens experience government digital services.â€ The results, presented online in the form of report cards, can also be downloaded.

Â 

Taylorâ€™s colors. Last year, Reddit user swiftdata1989 published a spreadsheet and visualization of the colors mentioned in Taylor Swiftâ€™s albums. Each spreadsheet row lists the album, song, specific color (e.g., â€œscarletâ€), closest generic color (e.g., red), number of times mentioned, and clarifying notes. Previously: Colors from the World Color Survey (DIP 2017.08.23), Wernerâ€™s Nomenclature of Colours (DIP 2021.11.17), and Bob Ross paintings (DIP 2020.12.09).

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send all hues of feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Groundwater levels, military surplus, study abroad, dot-gov metadata, and Taylorâ€™s colors.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.01.24 edition
entry.content:
Police data metadata, historical fishing intensity, Medicaid offices, Seine water quality, and human heights.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Aditya Dahiya has used data on movie theaters in eight Indian cities (featured in DIP 2017.11.08) and Netflix viewership data (featured in DIP 2023.12.20) to demonstrate custom color scales and legends with ggplot2. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Police data metadata. The Police Data Accessibility Project is compiling a meta-dataset of police records: where to find them online, what time period they cover, how often theyâ€™re updated, and other characteristics. The searchable, downloadable dataset includes links to 1,700+ resources, such as traffic stop datasets, crime maps, use-of-force reports, contract and policy listings, and many other types of records, across hundreds of agencies. The team also maintains a dataset of 23,000+ criminal legal agencies. Related: The Vera Institute of Justiceâ€™s Police Data Transparency Index, which scored 90+ local police agencies across 10 categories of data transparency; its methodology page links to a more detailed, downloadable spreadsheet.

Â 

Historical fishing intensity. Yannick Rousseau et al. have generated a series of datasets estimating annual fishing effort from 1950 to 2017 by country, year, gear type, vessel length, sector (industrial, artisanal motorized, and artisanal unmotorized), and category of species targeted. The datasets provide â€œinformation on number of vessels, engine power, gross tonnage, and nominal effort,â€ a metric that multiplies the engine power by the number of days at sea. Their sources include â€œa range of publicly available sources, governmental reports, and grey literatureâ€. Related: Co-author Reg A. Watsonâ€™s Global Fisheries Landings dataset, which estimates â€œcommercial, small-scale, illegal and unreported fisheries catch,â€ also since 1950. Previously: Global Fishing Watchâ€™s fishing effort datasets, based on vessel tracking signals (DIP 2021.01.13).

Â 

Medicaid offices, geocoded. Paul R. Shafer et al. have created a dataset of 3,000+ Medicaid offices in the US, identified via state and county government websites. The team of Boston University researchers, who focused on â€œpublic-facing Medicaid offices providing enrollment support,â€ have provided each officeâ€™s agency name, state, city, and address, and latitude/longitude coordinates (primarily sourced via the US Census Bureauâ€™s geocoder).

Â 

Seine water quality. Ahead of the 2024 Summer Olympics, Paris has been trying to decontaminate the Seine river to swimmable levels. But the cityâ€™s efforts appear to be falling short, according to government water testing data obtained, published, and analyzed by Mathieu Lehot-Couette, a reporter at Franceinfo.fr. The records include results from periodic samples taken at 14 points along the river, which Lehot-Couette has standardized into a spreadsheet of 1,400+ measurements of E. coli and enterococci between 2015 and 2023.

Â 

Human heights. Economic historians JÃ¶rg Baten and Matthias Blum have assembled a dataset on average male heights by decade and country. The estimates, derived from hundreds of scholarly and statistical sources, stretch back several centuries and span 140+ countries. A related resource page also provides individual-level data compiled by Baten and others, such as the heights of 1,000+ 19th-century Bavarian military conscripts. [h/t Karsten Johansson]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send head-to-toe feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Police data metadata, historical fishing intensity, Medicaid offices, Seine water quality, and human heights.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.01.17 edition
entry.content:
RSV, subnational economic output, environmental treaties, Chicagoâ€™s â€œmenu money,â€ and Star Trek chairs.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Andy Pickering recently analyzed and visualized the US Large-Scale Solar Photovoltaic Database featured in DIP 2023.12.13. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

RSV. The US CDCâ€™s Respiratory Syncytial Virus Hospitalization Surveillance Network collects data on hospital admissions due to lab-confirmed RSV at acute-care facilities in 58 counties, across 12 states. The CDC uses the data to estimate weekly hospitalization rates â€” overall as well as by age group, race/ethnicity, and sex. Those rates, which go back to 2016â€“17 for adults and 2018â€“19 for minors, are available via an interactive dashboard and downloadable dataset. Related: The network is part of a broader system that also monitors influenza and COVID-19 hospitalizations. Also: The European Respiratory Virus Surveillance Summary, launched in October by the European CDC and World Health Organization, features weekly data tables and epidemiological summaries.

Â 

Subnational economic output. Leonie Wenz et al.â€™s Database of Sub-national Economic Output (DOSE) provides â€œharmonised data on reported economic output from 1,661 sub-national regions across 83 countries from 1960 to 2020.â€ Those regions include, for instance, Turkeyâ€™s 81 provinces, Japanâ€™s 47 prefectures, and Kenyaâ€™s 47 counties. For each year, the dataset indicates the monetary value of the regionâ€™s total economic output, and often also subtotals for the agricultural, manufacturing, and services sectors. While previous projects have used interpolation to estimate similar figures, DOSE avoids that approach, instead assembling its data only from â€œstatistical agencies, yearbooks and academic literature.â€

Â 

Environmental treaties. Ronald B. Mitchellâ€™s International Environmental Agreements Database Project tracks 4,000+ such arrangements, defined as â€œan intergovernmental document intended as legally binding with a primary stated purpose of preventing or managing human impacts on natural resources.â€ Examples include the Indus Water Treaty (1960) and Convention on Nuclear Safety (1994). The projectâ€™s datasets characterize each agreement (e.g., its name, signature date, type, subject) and 100,000+ â€œmembership actionsâ€ by participating countries. The project also tracks various â€œnon-agreements,â€ such as memoranda of understanding. [h/t Jean-FrÃ©dÃ©ric Morin et al.]

Â 

Chicagoâ€™s â€œmenu money.â€ Chicagoâ€™s 50 wards can each receive up to $1.5 million annually to spend on infrastructure projects such as street lighting, sidewalk repair, art murals, and park improvements. Each wardâ€™s city council representative typically decides how to spend this so-called â€œmenu money,â€ although some let residents allocate a portion. The city publishes menu money spending reports, but only as PDFs. So data researcher Jake J. Smith has programmatically converted twelve years of those PDFs (2012â€“2023) into a spreadsheet containing 28,000 line items. Each entry indicates the year, ward, line itemâ€™s cost, category, program, and description (often the location of the project).

Â 

Star Trek chairs. Ex Astris Scientia, run by Bernd Schneider since 1998, contains much of what you might expect from a Star Trek fan site, such as episode summaries, starship catalogs, and an extensive encyclopedia. But it also publishes some more esoteric inventories, such as HTML tables of commercially available chairs and lamps that have appeared on screen. [h/t Duncan Geere]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send commercially available feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: RSV, subnational economic output, environmental treaties, Chicagoâ€™s â€œmenu money,â€ and Star Trek chairs.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.12.20 edition
entry.content:
Dengue, workforce training providers, Antarctic ice sheets, finance ministers, and Netflix viewership.

Â 

ğŸ™ Just released: The fifth and final main episode of the second season of the Data Is Plural podcast. This episodeâ€™s guests are George Ho and Saul Pwanson, whose crossword datasets were featured in DIP 2021.09.22 and DIP 2016.03.09, respectively. ICYMI: Episode 1 (jean pocket sizes), Episode 2 (US income distributions and dynamics), Episode 3 (the Missing Migrants Project), and Episode 4 (Canadian wildfires).

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader George Gorczynski has built visualizations of natural disasters (using the Geocoded Disasters Dataset featured in DIP 2021.03.17) and gender inequality in street naming (using the Mapping Diversity data featured in DIP 2023.09.06). Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.

Â 

Dengue. OpenDengue, a new project based at the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, â€œaims to build and maintain a database of dengue case counts for every dengue-affected country worldwide since 1990 or earlier.â€ (According to a 2013 study cited by the WHO, the virus causes an estimated 96 million symptomatic infections per year.) Drawing from a range of sources, the team has collected weekly, monthly, and/or annual national counts from 100+ countries so far and welcomes contributions. For each count, the projectâ€™s datasets indicate what was being counted: suspected cases, confirmed cases, probable cases, or a combination. For several dozen countries, the data also contain sub-national counts â€” including for 5,000+ municipalities in Brazil and all 70+ Thai provinces. [h/t Sarah Newey]

Â 

Workforce training providers. The Workforce Almanac, launched last month by the Harvard-based Project on Workforce, maps â€œalmost 17,000 providers of workforce training, which we have defined as short-term (lasting less than two years), post-high school training opportunities in which learners gain work-relevant skills to help them find a job.â€ The dataset lists each organizationâ€™s name, address, city, state, coordinates, and various categorizations. To build it, the team merged and cleaned data from four sources: the Department of Laborâ€™s Registered Apprenticeship Partners Information Database System (RAPIDS) and TrainingProviderResults.gov, IRS nonprofit registrations, and the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS).

Â 

Antarctic ice sheets. The Scientific Committee on Antarctic Researchâ€™s Bedmap Data Portal provides access to â€œice bed, surface and thickness point data from all Antarctic geophysical campaigns since the 1950s.â€ In an accompanying paper, Alice C. FrÃ©mand et al. describe the process they undertook to standardize decades of ice-survey data and to publish the outputs based on â€œfindable, accessible, interoperable, and reusableâ€ (FAIR) data principles. In all, the records contain â€œ82 million data points collected as part of 277 campaigns,â€ spanning three generations of data. Previously: Antarctic geology (DIP 2023.05.31).

Â 

Finance ministers. Brenna Armstrong et al. have compiled a dataset of 2,900+ people who served as a national finance minister or equivalent position between 1972 and 2017. For each of their 3,200+ tenures, the dataset lists the ministerâ€™s name, country, year-month started/ended, gender, whether the minister received an advanced economics education, and whether theyâ€™d be considered a technocrat â€” i.e., someone who had policy expertise but hadnâ€™t held elective office. [h/t Phenomenal World]

Â 

Netflix viewership. In late 2021, Netflix began publishing downloadable datasets of the 10 most popular movies and TV shows each week, overall and by country. Last week the company published a new data report, which lists all 18,000+ titles viewed for 50,000+ hours on the platform in the first half of 2023. The report, which Netflix says it will publish twice a year, indicates each titleâ€™s name, release date, approximate hours viewed, and whether it was available globally. [h/t Avi Levin + Saul Pwanson]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send globally available feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Dengue, workforce training providers, Antarctic ice sheets, finance ministers, and Netflix viewership.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.12.13 edition
entry.content:
NYC shelter counts, US solar facilities, state supreme court justices, antimicrobial peptides, and Finland transport.

Â 

ğŸ™ Just released:Â The fourth episodeÂ of the second season of theÂ Data Is Plural podcast. This episodeâ€™s guest isÂ Bruce Macnab, head of Canadaâ€™s Wildland Fire Information System,Â featured inÂ DIP 2023.06.14. Stay tuned next week for this seasonâ€™s fifth and final main episode â€” and look out early next year for a bonus, crossover episode byÂ Loud Numbers, which willÂ sonifyÂ Canadian wildfire data.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Richard Brath has constructed a hierarchical text visualization of the London Lives projectâ€™s 18th-century coroner inquests data, featured in DIP 2019.04.17. The visualization appears in Brathâ€™s â€œLiteral Encoding: Text is a first-class data encodingâ€ paper and related book. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

NYC shelter counts. Every night, tens of thousands of people stay in New York City homeless shelters, which are managed by a half-dozen city agencies. Earlier this year, thanks to a 2022 law, the city began publishing monthly statistics on shelter population counts and average lengths of stay, broken down by agency, program, and family composition. One agency, the Department of Homeless Services, publishes some structured daily data, but shares its most comprehensive daily counts as a nightly-overwritten PDF. So Patrick Spauster and Adrian Nesta have built a data pipeline to scrape, archive, and standardize these datasets, and have partnered with City Limits to revamp the publicationâ€™s shelter population tracker. In October, more than 143,000 people slept in the cityâ€™s shelters, the highest monthly count on record.

Â 

US solar facilities. The United States Large-Scale Solar Photovoltaic Database, released last month, maps and describes 3,600+ solar power facilities with capacities of at least 1 megawatt. The project, a collaboration between the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and US Geological Survey, includes an online viewer, downloadable database, and API (with example usage). The data indicate each facilityâ€™s boundary and centroid coordinates, state, county, and site type, plus data extracted from EIA Form 860, such as capacity, axis type, tilt angle, and more. Related: A map and dataset of Illinois solar installations, large and small, compiled by volunteers at Chi Hack Night. Previously: The Global Energy Monitorâ€™s Global Solar Power Tracker (DIP 2022.06.01). [h/t Kate Martin + Derek Eder]

Â 

State supreme court justices. David A. Hughes et al., building on prior work, have calculated ideology scores (on a conservative-liberal continuum) for 1,600+ state supreme court justices from 1970 to 2019. For each justice and year, the dataset provides the justiceâ€™s state, last name, political affiliation, the authorsâ€™ ideology score estimates, and ideology scores produced by two other research teams. Previously: Ideology estimates for state legislators (DIP 2020.01.01), members of Congress (DIP 2023.03.01), and local populations (DIP 2023.08.02).

Â 

Antimicrobial peptides. In a recent journal article, the University of Nebraska Medical Centerâ€™s Guangshun Wang discusses the history and future of the Antimicrobial Peptide Database, which his lab launched more than 20 years ago. The database now catalogs 3,500+ such molecules, which play an important role in the innate immune system. You can search the peptides by name, structural and functional properties, source organism, and other criteria, and can download their amino acid sequences.

Â 

Finland transport. The Finnish Transport and Communications Agencyâ€™s public datasets span a range of topics, including the radio spectrum, mobile networks, cybersecurity, registered vehicles, ships, aircraft, and more. It also publishes downloadable statistics unavailable from many other countries, such as passenger carsâ€™ inspection failure rates by make, model, and year and driving exam results. [h/t Stagnant]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send road-safe feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: NYC shelter counts, US solar facilities, state supreme court justices, antimicrobial peptides, and Finland transport.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.12.06 edition
entry.content:
Nuclear weapon systems, social media platform policies, EU court cases, the Fedâ€™s â€œdot plots,â€ and 350,757 coin flips.

Â 

ğŸ™ Just released: The third episode of the second season of the Data Is Plural podcast. This episodeâ€™s guest is Julia Black, coordinator of the International Organization for Migrationâ€™s Missing Migrants Project, featured in DIP 2020.01.15. And ICYMI: Episode 1 (on jean pocket sizes) and Episode 2 (on US income distributions and dynamics).

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader David Johnston has built an interactive visualization of the Kia/Hyundai theft data featured in DIP 2023.10.11. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Nuclear weapon systems. The Council on Strategic Risksâ€™s Nuclear Weapon Systems Project aims â€œto document every type of nuclear weapon system ever deployedâ€ by China, France, Russia, the UK, and the US â€” the five â€œnuclear weapon statesâ€ per the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The projectâ€™s core dataset, launched last week, currently covers 250+ such systems. For each, it provides the systemâ€™s name, country, type (gravity bomb, torpedo, ICBM, etc.), military branches in charge of deployment, â€œmissionâ€ (tactical, strategic, or hybrid), years introduced and retired, replacement system, and more. Previously: Nuclear stockpiles (DIP 2022.11.02), nuclear explosions (DIP 2016.03.23), and uranium/plutonium facilities (DIP 2016.02.24).

Â 

Social media platform policies. The Platform Governance Archive â€œcollects and curates policies of major social media platforms in a long-term perspective.â€ The initial version of the archive used the Wayback Machine retrospectively to collect policies published 2005â€“2021 by Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube. The new version, part of a re-launch this year, uses web-scraping to track 18 platformsâ€™ policies daily. Related: The new version is a collaboration with the Open Terms Archive, an evolution of work by Franceâ€™s Ambassador for Digital Affairs to track terms of service, featured in DIP 2021.01.20.

Â 

EU court cases. The IUROPA Projectâ€™s CJEU Database â€œis the most complete collection of research-ready data about the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) and European Union (EU) law.â€ Developed from several official sources by Stein Arne Brekke et al., the database provides tables of all cases (45,000+), parties (85,000+), proceedings (47,000+), decisions (50,000+), citations (1,000,000+), judges (270+), and more from the courtâ€™s inception in 1952 through 2022. That first table, for instance, lists each caseâ€™s name, ID, sub-court, year, judgment status, appeal status, and additional details. [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

The Fedâ€™s â€œdot plots.â€ Four times a year, the US Federal Reserveâ€™s Federal Open Market Committee publishes its â€œSummary of Economic Projectionsâ€ reports. Those reports contain a chart thatâ€™s come to be known as the Fedâ€™s â€œdot plot,â€ which tallies the committee membersâ€™ forecasts of the year-end federal funds interest rate for this and subsequent years. Upon noticing â€œno simple, easy-to-access data fileâ€ of the chartâ€™s information, journalist Ben Welsh wrote a scraper to create such a file, currently covering 2018â€“present. Previously: Federal Reserve communications collected by Agam Shah et al. (DIP 2023.08.09).

Â 

Many coin flips. â€œMany people have flipped coins but few have stopped to ponder the statistical and physical intricacies of the process,â€ write FrantiÅ¡ek BartoÅ¡ et al., introducing an experiment in which â€œa group of 48 people (i.e., all but three of the co-authors) tossed coins of 46 different currencies Ã— denominations and obtained a total number of 350,757 coin flips.â€ The authors have published the raw results, images of each coin, and videos of the flips. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send flipped feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Nuclear weapon systems, social media platform policies, EU court cases, the Fedâ€™s â€œdot plots,â€ and 350,757 coin flips.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.11.29 edition
entry.content:
Political violence and protests, seafloor depths, payment choices, legal cannabis sales, and romance book covers.

Â 

ğŸ™ Just released: The second episode of the second season of the Data Is Plural podcast. This episodeâ€™s guest is Illenin Kondo one of the economists behind the Income Distributions and Dynamics in America (IDDA) dataset and resource, featured in DIP 2023.10.11. Click here to listen.

Â 

ğŸ™ And ICYMI: The first episode of the season, with Jan Diehm and Amber Thomas discussing their data-driven investigation into jeans pockets (DIP 2018.08.22).

Â 

Political violence and protests. The Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project â€œcollects real-time data on the locations, dates, actors, fatalities, and types of all reported political violence and protest events around the world.â€ First featured in DIP six years ago, ACLED has since expanded substantially. Most notably, its datasets are no longer limited to Africa and Asia; they now cover all countries and territories. The project has updated its event types â€” battles, â€œexplosions/remote violence,â€ violence against civilians, riots, protests, and â€œstrategic developmentsâ€ â€” and added sub-categories. It has also developed topical subsets, such political violence targeting women and violence against local officials and administrators.

Â 

Seafloor depths. The International Hydrographic Organizationâ€™s Data Centre for Digital Bathymetry, established in 1990, hosts dozens of terabytes of â€œoceanic depth soundings acquired with multibeam and singlebeam sonars by hydrographic, oceanographic and industry vessels during surveys or while on passage.â€ It also provides access to depth data crowdsourced from mariners, who agree to attach logging devices to their shipsâ€™ echosounders. Read more: â€œCan a map of the ocean floor be crowdsourced?â€ by ocean journalist Laura Trethewey for the BBC. Previously: The Arctic seafloor (DIP 2020.07.22) from the General Bathymetric Chart of the Oceans, another IHO project. [h/t Walt Hickey]

Â 

How we pay. The Survey and Diary of Consumer Payment Choice, run annually by a collaboration of Federal Reserve Banks, â€œaims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the payment behavior of US consumers.â€ The survey component inquires about demographics, habits, and preferences, including respondentsâ€™ use of different payment methods (cash, check, credit card, debit card, mobile payments, et cetera). The diary component asks participants to record their account balances and every transaction they made during a three-day period. The most recent iteration features responses from 4,700+ people in October 2022; the data downloads include summary tables and anonymized microdata. [h/t Chartr]

Â 

Legal cannabis sales. Coloradoâ€™s Department of Revenue publishes a range of data about the stateâ€™s legal marijuana industry, including spreadsheets of monthly sales totals and taxes collected by county and medical/retail status. Other states that have legalized recreational marijuana and publish downloadable, machine-readable sales data include California, Connecticut, Illinois, Maine, Massachusetts, New Mexico, Oregon, and Washington. Those with data in PDFs include Arizona, Maryland, Michigan, Montana, New Jersey, and Rhode Island. [h/t Cody Winchester]

Â 

Romance book covers. â€œWhat does a happily ever after look like?â€ asks Alice Liang, whose visual essay in The Pudding examines the covers of 1,400+ books featured in Publishers Weeklyâ€™s announcements for the genre. Liangâ€™s spreadsheet provides each bookâ€™s title, author, publisher, publication date, announcement year/season, ISBN, cover image, and several assessments of the cover: whether its style is photorealistic or illustrated, whether it features someone partially undressed, and whether it depicts at least one person of color.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send genre-bending feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Political violence and protests, seafloor depths, payment choices, legal cannabis sales, and romance book covers.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.11.22 edition
entry.content:
Food access, strategic ecology, Australian law, electricity-balancing incentives, and lunar craters.

Â 

ğŸ™ The Data Is Plural podcast is back, with a new season of 15-minute interviews that dive deeper into DIP-noted datasets. Season 2â€™s first guests are Jan Diehm and Amber Thomas, whose data-driven investigation into pocket sizes was featured in DIP 2018.08.22. Click here to listen to the episode.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ â€œOne of Californiaâ€™s fastest-growing areas may become a city. Charts show how rare that isâ€ â€” an article published by reader Nami Sumida in the San Francisco Chronicle last week â€” uses Christopher B. Goodmanâ€™s municipal incorporation dataset featured in DIP 2023.03.22. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Food access. The USDAâ€™s Food Access Research Atlas estimates how far people have to travel to buy healthy groceries. For any given Census tract, the projectâ€™s interactive map and downloadable data indicate the number of residents living within 0.5, 1, 10, and 20 miles of â€œthe nearest supermarket, supercenter, or large grocery store.â€ They provide similar counts for each tractâ€™s low-income residents, children, seniors, people without vehicle access, SNAP recipients, and by race/ethnicity. The most recent update uses 2019 data; prior versions are available for 2015 and 2010. Related: The distances are based partly on the USDAâ€™s database of SNAP-authorized retailers. [h/t Sayli Benadikar]

Â 

Strategic ecology. The National Ecological Observatory Network operates 81 study sites across the US, strategically selected to represent a diversity of â€œvegetation, landforms, and ecosystem dynamics.â€ Examples include Caribou Creek in Alaska, Lyndon B. Johnson National Grassland in Texas, and Guanica Forest in Puerto Rico. The networkâ€™s data portal provides downloads and an API for 160+ datasets, such as site elevations, downed wood log surveys, soil microbe compositions, and fish DNA sequences. Related: Ben G. Weinstein et al. recently used the networkâ€™s remote sensing data to generate a dataset estimating the location, size, likely species, and status of 100 million individual trees at 24 of the sites. [h/t Sharon Machlis]

Â 

Australian law. In a recent blog post, Umar Butler describes the process of building the Open Australian Legal Corpus, â€œfrom months-long negotiations with governments to reverse engineering ancient web technologies to hacking together a multitude of different solutions for extracting text from documents.â€ The corpus, â€œthe largest open database of Australian law,â€ lists the text, type, jurisdiction, source, citation, and URL of 220,000+ documents. It includes â€œevery in force statute and regulation in the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and Norfolk Island, in addition to thousands of bills and hundreds of thousands of court and tribunal decisions.â€ [h/t Susie Cambria]

Â 

Electricity-balancing incentives. Jim Moranâ€™s VPP Data tracks programs in the US that incentivize homeowners (and others) to participate in virtual power plants â€” collections of internet-connected batteries and other â€œdistributed energy resourcesâ€ that utilities can use to balance supply and demand. The projectâ€™s main spreadsheet tracks 120+ programs and their variations, spanning 20+ states and Puerto Rico. Each entry lists the program name, date announced, status, state, utility, sector, VPP platform, market aggregator, devices covered, monetary incentives, and more.

Â 

Moon dents. The Lunar Crater Database, compiled by Stuart Robbins, provides the location and dimensions of 1.3 million lunar impact craters. The catalog, â€œmanually identified and measuredâ€ from lunar orbiter imagery, is â€œapproximately complete for all craters larger than about 1â€“2 km in diameter.â€ Related: Craters on Venus, Ganymede, and Callisto, from the Lunar and Planetary Institute. Previously: A 1:5,000,000-scale map of Earthâ€™s moon (DIP 2021.12.08). [h/t Allen Downey]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send concave feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Food access, strategic ecology, Australian law, electricity-balancing incentives, and lunar craters.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.11.15 edition
entry.content:
Trans rights, home schooling, migrant arrivals in Italy, toxic wastewater spills, and coffee tasting.

Â 

ğŸ™ Season 2 of the Data Is Plural podcast is arriving soon. To subscribe via your favorite podcast-listening app, click here.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Alexandra F published an analysis of US honey consumption and production over time, using data from USDA reports featured in DIP 2022.01.05. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Trans rights. Myles Williamsonâ€™s Trans Rights Indicator Project â€œprovides insight into the legal situations transgender people faced in 173 countries from 2000 to 2021.â€ The projectâ€™s dataset is â€œthe only public dataset covering trans rights with wide spatial and temporal coverage (to my knowledge),â€ Williamson writes. For each country-year combination, it â€œincludes 14 indicators that capture the presence or absence of laws related to criminalization, legal gender recognition, and anti-discrimination protections.â€ For instance: Does the country require a psychological diagnosis before someone can change their gender on identity documents?

Â 

Home schooling. The Washington Post has gathered data on home-school enrollment figures in dozens of US states and 6,700+ school districts over the past six academic years. Post reporters, with help from students at American University, â€œtrawled state websites, contacted education officials in all 50 states and the District of Columbia and submitted multiple public records requestsâ€ to build the dataset, released last week. Each entry indicates the state/district, school year, and the number of students registered for home schooling. Read more: The Postâ€™s analysis, which â€œreveals that a dramatic rise in home schooling at the onset of the pandemic has largely sustained itself through the 2022-23 academic year, defying predictions [â€¦].â€ [h/t Meghan Hoyer]

Â 

Migrant arrivals in Italy. The Dati Bene Comune campaignâ€™s latest initiative, Liberiamoli tutti! (Letâ€™s free them all!), aims to improve the availability of Italian government data. Its first project has been to convert the interior ministryâ€™s statistics on migrant arrivals from PDF reports into spreadsheets. The extracted information includes daily counts of sea arrivals, twice-monthly totals by nationality, and the number of people in reception centers by center type and Italian region. A nice shout-out: Liberiamoli tutti! says itâ€™s inspired by Data Is Pluralâ€™s sibling, The Data Liberation Project.

Â 

Toxic wastewater spills. For a recent Inside Climate News investigation, Martha Pskowski and Peter Aldhous wrangled data on 10,000+ wastewater spills reported by oil and gas companies to the Texas government between 2013 and 2022. These â€œspill logsâ€ â€” obtained through public records requests, then cleaned and standardized by the journalists â€” correspond to more than 148 million gallons of â€œproduced water,â€ a byproduct of drilling and fracking. The data indicate each spillâ€™s date, location, facility, operator, type of operation, volume of wastewater released, volume recovered, and much more.

Â 

Coffee tasting. Last month, British YouTuber (and former World Barista Champion) James Hoffman virtually hosted the Great American Coffee Taste Test, during which thousands of people simultaneously blind-tasted the same four coffees. Hoffman has published a video summarizing the results, as well as a spreadsheet of anonymized survey responses from 4,000+ participants. It includes tastersâ€™ demographics, general coffee drinking habits and preferences, assessments of the four coffees, and more. [h/t Dan Brady]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send freshly roasted feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Trans rights, home schooling, migrant arrivals in Italy, toxic wastewater spills, and coffee tasting.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.11.01 edition
entry.content:
Opioid settlements, financial offshoring, minority-serving colleges, childcare inspections, and two Zurich buses.

Â 

ğŸ”„ The Marine Regions project, featured in DIP 2021.09.29, has released version 12 of its maritime boundaries dataset, adding â€œnew and more detailed line typesâ€ and â€œupdated with newly established baselines, treaties, and court rulings.â€

Â 

Opioid settlements. OpioidSettlementTracker.com, run by lawyer Christine Minhee, asks: â€œWill opioid settlements be spent in ways that bolster the public health response to drug use?â€ Minhee has compiled a series of spreadsheets to help answer that question. They track the status and reported values of settlements between 14 companies (opioid manufacturers, distributors, and others) and US states (plus DC and Puerto Rico), statesâ€™ plans for spending those settlements, and their promises to publicly report such spending. Read more: â€œ$50 Billion in Opioid Settlement Cash Is on the Way. Weâ€™re Tracking How Itâ€™s Spent,â€ a KFF Health News article using Minheeâ€™s data, part of a broader project on the topic.

Â 

Financial offshoring. The Atlas of the Offshore World â€” â€œa new effort by the EU Tax Observatory,â€ a research group based at the Paris School of Economics â€” aims â€œto inform the global debate around international tax evasion and avoidance.â€ Its four main datasets provide country-level estimates of international profit shifting, offshore financial wealth, offshore real estate ownership, and 50+ years of effective tax rates. Read more: The teamâ€™s â€œGlobal Tax Evasion Report 2024â€ and â€œThe History Behind the Atlas of the Offshore World.â€ [h/t Matt Collin]

Â 

Minority-serving colleges. The MSI Data Project provides a dashboard and dataset focused on colleges and universities that qualify federally as minority-serving institutions either through their mission (e.g., HBCUs) or through enrollment. The project examines institutionsâ€™ funding status, location, student body, and degree granting for 2017â€“2021. It draws on records from the Department of Educationâ€™s â€œeligibility matricesâ€ for each MSI designation and the agencyâ€™s Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS). As seen in: â€œBeyond the Rankings: The College Welcome Guide,â€ by The Hechinger Reportâ€™s Fazil Khan, incorporating data from both IPEDS and the MSI Data Project. [h/t Sarah Butrymowicz]

Â 

Childcare inspections. â€œAcross 41 states, one in ten licensed daycare facilities is overdue for an inspection,â€ according to an analysis by USAFacts, which gathered inspection-timing data for 148,000 facilities. The analysisâ€™s downloadable datasets indicate the number of facilities overdue (versus on-time or unknown) in each state and county, as well as the distribution of days-since-last-inspection in each state. Most of the inspection data had to be programmatically collected from state portals, according to Amber Thomas, except for California, which publishes bulk data (including inspection dates) about all childcare facilities.

Â 

Two Zurich buses. Fabio Widmer et al.â€™s ZTBus dataset provides detailed data from 1,409 â€œdriving missionsâ€ of two electric public transit buses in Zurich, Switzerland. Each mission typically represents a full dayâ€™s operation. The records, which span early 2019 to late 2022, include â€œtime series that represent the power demand, propulsion system, odometry, global position, ambient temperature, door openings, number of passengers, and the dispatch patterns within the public transportation network of the two vehicles.â€

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Dispatch your feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Opioid settlements, financial offshoring, minority-serving colleges, childcare inspections, and two Zurich buses.
